content: “We no longer pay for pagan burials”. “We accuse everyone but ourselves on social media.” We, we, we, all the way home. Mr. Sledge, don’t you know the old proverb about change? “Change starts with ‘I’”! Whenever you find yourself writing long statements about what “we” are doing wrong then try this experiment: Replace the first-person plurals with first person singulars. If you’re not just as filled with gusto to say “I accuse others on social media but not myself” then you’re just using “we” as a way to hide what you’re really doing: pharisaical virtue signalling. It’s an easy trap to fall into: It’s hard to say “You guys accuse everyone but yourselves!”, so people cushion it by saying “we”. But the unspoken premise is that, as the one making the indictment, the messenger is more morally aware and thus exempt. It’s like that old saying “Whenever you find yourself saying ‘someone should’ replace ‘someone’ with ‘I’ and see if it still seems so important and worth doing”
